'''Students Against Destructive Decisions''', formerly '''Students Against Driving Drunk''' (SADD) is an organization whose aim is to prevent accidents from students taking potentially destructive decisions.
==Mission== The mission of the SADD chapter is to help people avoid the dangers of drinking and driving. Today, their mission has expanded to deal with underage drinking, other drug use, risky and impaired driving, discrimination, bullying, and other destructive decisions.
==Profile== SADD's approach involves young people presenting education and prevention messages to their peers through school and community activities. Projects include peer-led classes and forums, teen workshops, conferences and rallies, prevention education and leadership training, awareness-raising activities and legislative work.
As of 2012, there are nearly 10,000 Middle school, high school, and college chapters with SADD advisors. There are 350,000 students actively participating ("members") in SADD chapters.
==History== SADD was founded by Robert Anastas at [[Wayland High School]] in [[Massachusetts]] in 1981. He and a group of 15 students developed the SADD concept and the Contract for Life. In 1982, SADD went national with offices founded throughout Massachusetts, [[Arizona]], [[Ohio]], [[North Carolina]], [[Connecticut]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[New Jersey]], [[Florida]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[West Virginia]], and [[Maine]]. In 1984, [[Dear Abby]] and [[Ask Ann Landers|Ann Landers]] printed the Contract for Life, suggesting to all readers that they request a copy from SADD.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2209&dat=19840117&id=e5orAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1vkFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6832,2617414|date=1984-01-17|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=2012-02-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2206&dat=19850523&id=36ImAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yQEGAAAAIBAJ&pg=1161,2187357|publisher=The Miami News|date=1985-05-23|accessdate=2012-02-05}}</ref> The SADD National office was inundated with 8,000 requests per week for six weeks. Also that year, "Contract for Life: The SADD Story" aired on [[CBS]] as a CBS Schoolbreak Special,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/10890/Contract-for-Life-The-S-A-D-D-Story/overview|title=Contract for Life: The S.A.D.D. Story (1985)|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=2012-02-05}}</ref> and Carl Olsen, the first SADD president at Wayland High School, was appointed by the Director of Health and Human Services as the only student to a three-year panel studying the alcoholism in America.
The following year, SADD offices were established in Germany and Guam. Also in 1985, SADD had its first presidential moment when [[Ronald Reagan|President Reagan]] met with SADD students of [[River Dell Regional High School|River Dell High School]] in New Jersey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=40073|title=The American Presidency Project: Ronald Reagan, Remarks at River Dell High School in Oradell, New Jersey|accessdate=2012-02-05}}</ref>
In 1989, SADD offices were established in schools in the Soviet Union. Also that year, the SADD National Board of Directors voted to cease accepting contributions from the alcohol industry.
In 1990, The American College of Physicians awarded the Edward G. Loveland Memorial Award to SADD for its contributions to the health field.
In 1992. William Cullinane became Executive Director of SADD.
The following year, the SADD Board of Directors voted not to accept funds from the alcohol industry.
In 1995, SADD received a letter of commendation from [[Bill Clinton|President Bill Clinton]]. The next year, Margaret Altstaetter, SADD Student of the Year 1995-1996, was invited to participate in the White House Leadership Conference on Youth, Drug Use and Violence.
==Chapters==
;Name Change A new name was adopted in 1997: Students Against Destructive Decisions.
In 1999, three Student Leadership Council members, Lynsey Ross, Jereme McBride, and Carrie LeBlanc, were appointed to the National Campaign to Prevent Teen Pregnancy Leadership Team.
SADD's Board of Directors appointed Penny Wells as its new President and Executive Director in 2000.
SADD launched its National Scholarship Program in 2002, awarding its first two scholarships the following year.
In 2004, Jacqueline Hackett, Executive Committee member of the 2003-2004 SADD National SLC, testified before the Congressional Subcommittee on Education Reform at the hearing "Preventing Underage Drinking: What Works?"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archives.republicans.edlabor.house.gov/archive/hearings/108th/edr/drinking021104/hackett.htm|title=Testimony of Jacqueline Hackett|accessdate=2012-02-05}}</ref>
In 2007, SADD attended a special White House event during which [[George W. Bush|President George W. Bush]] highlighted a decline in youth drug use from 2001 to 2007.
In 2008, SADD partnered with the White House's [[National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign]] to raise awareness about the link between stress and drug use among teens and about prescription drug use.
By 2009, the SADDvocate, SADD's monthly e-newsletter for students and advisors, had reached more than 11,000 subscribers.
In 2010 SADD successfully lobbied for the introduction of the STARS (Students Taking Action for Road Safety) Act. In October, SADD received an international drug abuse prevention award from the Queen of Sweden. Also, [[Mentor Foundation|The Mentor International Foundation]] presented SADD with the 2010 Youth Initiative Award for "Mobilizing the Community: Youth Taking the Lead." SADD also took part in the [[Oprah Winfrey]] led "No phone zone day."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oprah.com/pressroom/Oprah-Winfreys-National-No-Phone-Zone-Day_1|title=Oprah-Winfreys-National-No-Phone-Zone-Day|accessdate=2012-02-05}}</ref>

{{sections|date=November 2018}} '''Teaching and Language Corpora''' (TaLC) is the name of a biennial conference that focusses on [[data-driven learning]] (DDL), an approach to language teaching and learning.
These conferences aim to promote classroom applications of language [[Corpus linguistics|corpora]], data-driven learning, as well as the creation of corpus-informed teaching materials and other resources, and foster discussion between practitioners, researchers and theorists from all over the world.
The use of corpora in language teaching has been growing steadily since [[Tim Johns]]'s pioneering work at Birmingham University in the last two decades of the 20th century.
==Conferences and publications==
TaLC has been held at various European universities since the 1990s.

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2011}} '''The Merchants of Bollywood''' is an [[Australia]]n [[Musical theatre|musical]] written and directed by Toby Gough. The show is about the history of the [[Bollywood]] film industry, and it is named after Hiralalji Merchant and his grand daughter [[Vaibhavi Merchant]], two notable [[India]]n [[choreographer]]s. The set and lighting design was by Liz Berry and the costumes were designed by Falguni Thakore and Bipin.<ref>[http://www.thisistheatre.com/regional/merchants-of-bollywood.html This is Theatre]</ref> The musical has been described as "an Indian version of the [[Billy Elliot]] story" and is choreographed by Vaibhavi Merchant.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/film/hooray-for-bollywood/2005/10/13/1128796652383.html | title=Hooray for Bollywood | date=15 October 2005 | last=Halliday | first=Claire | publisher=[[The Age]] | accessdate=29 June 2008 }}</ref> It was the first ever [[Bollywood]] production to tour straight from [[Film City]] in [[Mumbai]]. When the show reached Australia in February 2008, there had been 400 performances seen by 500,000 patrons.<ref>[http://www.news.com.au/perthnow/story/0,21598,23207206-5011022,00.html Perth Now (Australia)]</ref> The show toured the [[United Kingdom]], various parts of [[Europe]], the [[United States]],<ref>[http://www.apunkachoice.com/scoop/bollywood/20060708-0.html Apunkachoice.com]</ref> [[Australia]],<ref>[http://www.news.com.au/perthnow/story/0,21598,23207206-5011022,00.html The Merchants of Bollywood] Perth Now (Australia)</ref> [[Canada]] and various parts of [[Asia]].
== Harvey Goldsmith == The [[English people|English]] music and arts [[Promoter (entertainment)|promoter]] [[Harvey Goldsmith]] presented a three-month tour of ''The Merchants Of Bollywood'' in UK during 2006. The show's Premier was at the [[Alexandra Theatre (Birmingham)|Alexandra Theatre]] [[Birmingham]] on 24 October 2006 and the final show of the UK tour took place at the [[Apollo Theatre]], London on 21 December 2006. A six-month tour of Europe followed in 2007.<ref>[http://www.harveygoldsmith.com/history2.php The Merchants of Bollywood] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080807141006/http://www.harveygoldsmith.com/history2.php |date=7 August 2008 }} Harvey Gold Smith.com</ref>

'''The September Concert''' is a charity which organises free public concerts on the anniversaries of [[9/11]]. It was founded by Haruko Smith, following the events of that day in 2001.<ref name="heraldsun" />
==History== [[File:NDI Sept Conc.jpg|thumb|250px|right|National Dance Institute at Rockefeller Plaza, 9/11/2010]]
Following the events of [[September 11 attacks|September 11th 2001]], Haruko Smith had the idea to fill the skies of NYC with music, inspired by the words of [[Aldous Huxley]]:
{{quote|After silence, that which can express the inexpressible, is music}}
The September Concert started out as a local grassroots charity and has grown to have a worldwide presence involving 10,000 volunteers and 15,000 musicians.<ref name="mission" />
[[File:ROME September Concert.jpg|thumb|250px|left| September Concert in Rome, 9/11/2010]]
The September Concert Foundation was incorporated in April 2002 as a 501(c)(3) public charity, inspired a small army of volunteers, and on September 11th 2002 the first September Concert was born. To date this organization has functioned solely through the efforts of volunteers.
In addition to the Board of Directors that included artists [[Jacques d'Amboise (dancer)|Jacques d'Amboise]] and [[Robert Rauschenberg]], The September Concert Foundation's Advisory Board was set up in 2002 with entertainers such as [[Quincy Jones]], [[Ravi Shankar]] and [[Christy Turlington Burns]]. Business leaders such as [[Tom Freston]] also joined in to help the foundation.
In 2010, 200 concerts were held all over the world on or near September 11. In [[New York City]] 58 concerts were held,<ref name="nytimes" /><ref name="nationaldance" /><ref name="eturbonews" /> joined by another 30 U.S. cities <ref name="mydesert"/> and 45 international cities including [[Edinburgh]] <ref name="mynewsdesk" /><ref name="inchoruschoir" /> [[London]], [[Rome]],<ref name="insidersabroad" /> [[Tamale]] (Ghana), [[Cap-Haïtien]] and [[Tokyo]].
==Mission and principles== [[File:September Concert Haiti.jpg|thumb|right| September Concert in Haiti, 9/10/2010]]
The mission of the September Concert Foundation is to bring communities together, to reaffirm the hope for peace, and to celebrate our universal humanity.
The foundation accomplishes this by inviting musicians of every age and genre to bring their gift of music anywhere space is available on the days surrounding the anniversary of September 11. Concerts are held in parks, gardens, schools, libraries, churches, restaurants, cafes, galleries, office buildings, stores, senior centers, community centers.
There are three principles behind the September Concert: *''Freedom'' for anyone to organise a concert with any genre and venue; *''Equality'' between the different musicians and styles of music; and *''Accessibility'': all of the concerts are free

{{Use British English|date=September 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Coord|52.2079|N|0.1345|E|type:landmark_region:GB|display=title}} [[File:Former Festival Theatre, Cambridge Geograph-2593449-by-Keith-Edkins.jpg|thumb|Interior of the former theatre in 2011]] The '''Theatre Royal''' was built in the Barnwell suburb of Cambridge, England, in 1816. It closed later that century but reopened as the '''Cambridge Festival Theatre''' from 1926 until 1935. The building, in which part of the interior of the theatre survives, is Grade II* listed.
== 19th century == William Wilkins (1751–1815){{sfn|Searby|1988|p=699}}, a building contractor, was proprietor of a chain of theatres in East Anglia known as the Norwich circuit. Performers included the [[Norwich Company of Comedians]], and performances had been given since the late 18th century on Stourbridge Common, north of the city of Cambridge, at the annual [[Stourbridge fair]].{{sfn|Searby|1988|p=693}} Wilkins and his son, also [[William Wilkins (architect)|William]] (1778–1839), built a theatre in 1807 at Sun Street, [[Barnwell, Cambridgeshire|Barnwell]]. The younger Wilkins – a prominent architect who had designed [[Downing College, Cambridge|Downing College]] and went on to work at other colleges and the National Gallery – designed a new theatre nearby to replace the 1807 building.{{sfn|Searby|1988|p=701}}
The building is on the south side of the Newmarket Road in the northeastern Cambridge suburb of Barnwell. Completed in 1816, the theatre was sited outside the boundary of the town owing to prohibition of theatrical entertainment by the [[Cambridge University|University]] authorities<ref name=listing>{{National Heritage List for England|num=1126148|desc=Arts Theatre Workshop and Store|access-date=26 September 2018}}</ref> (a 1737 act "for the More Effectual Preventing the Unlawful Playing of Interludes within the Precincts of the Two Universities ..." forbade the performance of all plays and operas within five miles of the town).{{sfn|Searby|1988|pp=696–700}}
On his father's death in 1815, Wilkins inherited the leases of the new site and six other theatres – Norwich, Bury St Edmunds, Colchester, Yarmouth, Ipswich and King's Lynn{{sfn|Searby|1988|pp=696–701}} – and continued to run them. Proprietorship passed to his son, W Bushby Wilkins, and a succession of lessees, but the Norwich circuit declined.{{sfn|Searby|1988|pp=696–706}} The theatre closed in 1878 and became a [[Nonconformism|nonconformist]] chapel.<ref name=independent>{{cite web|title=The Festival Theatre, Cambridge|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/the-festival-theatre-cambridge-1568393.html|website=The Independent|date=17 January 1995|last=Davies|first=Andrew John|accessdate=26 September 2018}}</ref>
== Cambridge Festival Theatre == [[Terence Gray]] (1895–1986) leased the building in 1926 and reopened it as the Cambridge Festival Theatre. The alleyway between the street and the building was enclosed to form a foyer. The interior was modernised, with the [[proscenium]] arch widened by the removal of the private boxes,<ref name="Justice-Malloy2009">{{cite book|author=Rhona Justice-Malloy|title=Theatre History Studies 2009|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=C6ioKbxcTHgC|date=9 August 2009|publisher=University of Alabama Press|isbn=978-0-8173-5554-8|pages=171–198}}</ref> and the introduction of electric lighting, a brick [[cyclorama]] and an early example of a [[revolving stage]].<ref name=listing /> The theatre was the country's "first permanent indoor performing space to be based on the design of a Greek open-air theatre".<ref name="Easterling1997">{{cite book|author=P. E. Easterling|title=The Cambridge Companion to Greek Tragedy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_kx9eeSJyeoC|date=2 October 1997|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-42351-9|page=305}}</ref>
The 'Festival' name reflected Grey's intention (unfulfilled) to promote summer festivals.<ref name="Justice-Malloy2009" /> The opening production on 22 November 1926 was ''[[Oresteia]]'', with choreography by [[Ninette de Valois]].<ref name="Easterling1997" />
Grey retired from the theatre in 1933<ref name=independent /> and went on to write on [[Taoism]] under the pseudonym "Wei Wu Wei". [[Norman Marshall (theatre director)|Norman Marshall]] worked at the theatre from 1926 and was its director from 1932 to 1933.
From 1927, [[Joseph Macleod]] was an actor and producer at the theatre, and in 1933 he became the theatre's director and lessee. Five of Macleod's plays were staged there, including ''Overture to Cambridge'' (1933) and ''A Woman Turned to Stone'' (1934). Under Macleod, the theatre became known for its avant-garde productions, and staging of lesser known works by great playwrights. Macleod staged some of [[Ezra Pound]]'s Noh plays, and also some [[Henrik Ibsen|Ibsen]] and [[Anton Chekhov|Chekhov]] (his company, The Cambridge Festival Players, was one of the first in the UK to stage Chekhov's play ''[[The Seagull]]''). The theatre was obliged to close due to financial difficulties in June 1935.{{Citation needed|date=September 2018}}
The building was recorded as [[Listed building#Categories of listed building|Grade II* listed]] in 1950.<ref name=listing /> From 1962 it was used by the [[Cambridge Arts Theatre|Arts Theatre]] as a workshop and store.<ref name=independent />
== Today == [[File:Cambridge Buddhist Centre, Newmarket Road.JPG|thumb|upright|Entrance in 2013]] The building is in use as a [[Buddhism in the United Kingdom|Buddhist]] centre.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cambridge Buddhist Centre|url=http://www.cambridgebuddhistcentre.com|website=|date=|accessdate=26 September 2018}}</ref>
[[Historic England]] describe the interior as "a virtually complete example of a Georgian theatre with a three-tiered horsehoe auditorium with the galleries supported on cast iron columns." and state that a painting of the Royal Arms remains above the [[proscenium]].<ref name=listing />
== References == {{Reflist}} * {{cite book|first=Peter|last=Searby|title=A History of the University of Cambridge: Vol 3: 1750–1870|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VoMPRz8nYQEC|year=1988|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-35060-0}}</ref>

{{About||the later theatre on this site|Théâtre Marigny}} {{Infobox theatre | name = Théâtre des Folies-Marigny | image = Théâtre des Folies-Marigny - Yon 2000pla26.jpg | image_size = 300px | image_alt = | caption = The Théâtre des Folies-Marigny,
sometime before its demolition in 1881 | image_map = | map_caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_map_caption = | address = [[Carré Marigny]] on the [[Champs-Élysées]], [[8th arrondissement of Paris]] | city = | country = | designation = | coordinates = {{coord|48.868631|2.313669|type:landmark|display=inline}} | architect = | owner = | tenant = | operator = | capacity = 300 | type = | opened = 1848 | reopened = | yearsactive = | rebuilt = | closed = | demolished =1881 | former names = {{Plainlist| * Salle Lacaze (1848–1852?) * Bouffes-Parisiens (1855–57, 59) * Théâtre Deburau (1858) * Théâtre Féérique (1861) * {{Nowrap|Théâtre des Champs-Élysées (1862–1863)}} * Folies Marigny (1864-1881) }} | production = | currentuse = | website = }} The '''Théâtre des Folies-Marigny''', a former Parisian theatre with a capacity of only 300 spectators, was built in 1848 by the [[Paris|City of Paris]] for a magician named Lacaze and was originally known as the '''Salle Lacaze'''.Faris 1980, p. 48. It was located at the east end of the Carré Marigny of the [[Champs-Élysées]], close to the Avenue Marigny, but faced west toward the [[Cirque National]] on the other side of the square. In 1855 the Salle Lacaze became the home of [[Jacques Offenbach]]'s [[Théâtre des Bouffes-Parisiens]], where he first built his reputation as a theatre composer. It was subsequently used unsuccessfully by several companies until 1864, when it again became a profitable operetta theatre called the Folies-Marigny. When this company diminished in popularity, the theatre was closed. It was demolished in 1881 and replaced with the Panorama Marigny which was converted into the [[Théâtre Marigny]] in 1893. ==Salle Lacaze== The first recorded entertainment use of the site dates to 1835, when a showman set up attractions at the Marigny junction. After the [[French Revolution of 1848]] a small theatre called the Salle Lacaze was built for a magician named Lacaze.Levin 2009, p. 401, identifies the theatre as the "Salle Lacaze". Yon 2000, p. 111, describes it as a "petit théâtre de magie que le 'physicien' Lacaze a rouvert..." ("little theatre of magic that the 'conjurer' Lacaze opened..."). In this context, "physicien" has been translated as "conjurer"; see Faris, p. 48; Kracauer 2002, p. 166; Spiers 1908 (''A New French-English General Dictionary''), [https://books.google.com/books?id=zSJXAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA151&dq=conjurer+OR+conjurer+physicien+intitle:french+intitle:dictionary&hl=en&ei=UidMTrbzJsXfiAKewMSpAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=physicien&f=false p. 537]. "Conjurer" is chiefly a British term, meaning "magician". It was a summer theatre, and in it he presented "legerdemain and amusing physical representations."Galignani 1852, [https://books.google.com/books?id=xQUoAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA495#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 495]. His theatre was also known as the '''Château d'Enfer''' (Castle of the Underworld).Duneton 1998, [https://books.google.com/books?id=8w4JAQAAMAAJ&q=%22Château+d'Enfer%22&dq=%22Château+d'Enfer%22&hl=en&ei=DwxLTreUCuPiiALT5tyhBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CEAQ6AEwBTgU p. 921]. Lacaze began losing money, and sometime after 1852 he closed down. ==Bouffes-Parisiens== [[File:Champs-Élysées, Palais de l'Industrie, Salle Lacaze, Cirque de l'Impératrice 1855 - Yon 2000pla27.jpg|thumb|upright=1.6|View of the [[:en:Palais de l'Industrie|Palais de l'Industrie]] on the far side the Champs-Élysées and the Carré Marigny with the [[Cirque de l'Impératrice]] at the front slightly left of center and the small Salle Lacaze (the first theatre of Offenbach's [[:en:Théâtre des Bouffes-Parisiens|Théâtre des Bouffes-Parisiens]]) across the square at the left]] In the spring of 1855 the composer [[Jacques Offenbach]] decided that the position of this modest wooden theatre was perfectly situated on the [[Carré Marigny]] to catch overspill traffic from the [[Exposition Universelle (1855)|Universal Exposition of 1855]]; after some modifications to the site he opened the [[Théâtre des Bouffes-Parisiens]] on 5 July 1855. The theatre had a capacity of only 300 spectators.Lamb 1992, p. 653, gives the capacity of the Salle Lacaze as 300. Gammond 1980, p. 37, says it had a seating capacity of 50. At the inaugural performance, Offenbach conducted four of his own works, the last of which was ''[[Les deux aveugles]]'', a one-act ''bouffonerie musicale'' about two swindling "blind" Parisian beggars. This little piece soon acquired an international reputation due to visitors from the Exposition and due to some controversy over its subject matter. Another notable premiere that summer was ''[[Le violoneux]]''. Further performances in the summer of 1855 were primarily of satirical sketches which only included a few musical numbers. The season, however, was so successful that Offenbach was able to resign his position as conductor of the [[Théâtre Français]].Faris 1980, pp. 51–52. This theatre was soon renamed Bouffes d'Été, as during the winter Offenbach directed the Bouffes d'Hiver in the [[Salle Choiseul]] on the rue Monsigny. The company also used the Salle Lacaze for the 1856, 1857, and 1859 summer seasons, and a total of 16 Offenbach pieces were premiered here by the Bouffes-Parisiens.Yon 2000, pp. 760–762. Offenbach sublet the hall to the mime [[Charles Deburau]] in 1858Yon 2000, p. 201. for one unsuccessful summer season (5 June to 14 October), when it was known as the '''Théâtre Deburau'''Lecomte 1905, [https://books.google.com/books?id=TKk-AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA22 p. 23]. or the '''Bouffes-Deburau'''.Gänzl 2001, p. 915. Deburau's season included the premieres of three 1-act pieces with music by [[Hervé (composer)|Hervé]]: ''Le voiturier'' (3 September), ''La belle espagnole'' (22 September), and ''Simple histoire'' (10 October). After Deburau, the theatre was again used by the Bouffes-Parisiens (1859). During the summer of 1860 Offenbach's company performed in Brusssels in June, while Offenbach himself went to Berlin to conduct the Berlin premiere of ''[[Orphée aux enfers]]'', and from July to early August the company performed in Lyon, leaving the Salle Lacaze empty.Yon 2000. Legislation enacted in March 1861 prevented the Bouffes-Parisiens from continuing to use both theatres, and their appearances at the Salle Lacaze were discontinued.Levin 2009, p. 401. ==Théâtre Féerique== On 1 January 1861 Raignard, inventor of a novel system of décors and tricks, applied for permission to use the theatre for presentations between 2 and 5 p.m. at reduced prices targeted at the "numerous persons of a variable population", whose occupations and limited means kept them from attending the theatre in the evening. He also intended it to help young authors, composers, and actors. By a ministerial order of 5 February his repertory was limited to one- and two-act ''[[comédies-vaudevilles]]'' and operettas (with at most 5 characters) and one- and two-act ''[[féeries]]'' (melodramas with magic) with tableaus, choruses, and dances. Performances were given under the name '''Théâtre Féerique des Champs-Élysées''' or '''Petit Théâtre Féerique des Champs-Élysées'''. After the failure of this enterprise, the director was dismissed by a decree of 3 August 1861, and on 7 August a second decree authorized the artists to continue performances as a society under the direction of Octave Guillier. This effort was abandoned, however, by 31 August.Wild 1989, p. 139. The theatre was next used by [[Charles Bridault]], who brought his '''Théâtre du Châlet des Îles''' in. This troupe had previously performed in the [[Bois de Boulogne]] from 13 June to 31 August. Their run of performances on the Champs-Élysées was short, however, only lasting from 3 to 10 September.Wild 1989, p. 69. ==Théâtre des Champs-Élysées== The theatre was next acquired by [[Céleste Mogador]] (Mme Lionel de Chabrillan), who had it renovated and rechristened as the '''Théâtre des Champs-Élysées''' (not to be confused with the later [[Théâtre des Champs-Élysées]] on the avenue Montaigne). She gave its direction to Eugène Audray-Deshorties, who received his authorization on 20 January 1862 and reopened the theatre on 19 April. His repertory was confined to one-, two-, and three-act ''comédies'' and ''vaudevilles'' (with ''[[intermèdes]]'' of song and dance) and operettas of one act, and was mainly borrowed from the [[Folies-Dramatiques]] (from the [[Boulevard du Temple]]), the Bouffes-Parisiens, and the [[Variétés]]. Due to poor management, he retired in September, and the theatre was rented to the troupe of the Folies-Dramatiques from 14 September to 6 November. Mme Chabrillan took over again in 1863. She applied for permission to open a café, with vocal concerts inside and instrumental concerts outside on the terrace, and provisionally entrusted its direction to Auguste Armand Bourgoin, who began on 22 June 1863. The theatre was sold to Louis-Émile Hesnard (the actor known as [[Montrouge (actor)|Montrouge]]) on 27 February 1864.Wild 1989, pp. 70–71. ==Folies-Marigny== [[File:Map with the Salle Lacaze (blue) on the Carré Marigny of the Champs-Élysées in Paris 1869 - U Chicago.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|The Folies-Marigny (blue) on an 1869 map of Paris]] [[Montrouge (actor)|Montrouge]] and his future wife [[Marguerite Macé-Montrouge|Mlle Macé]], turned it into a popular success as the '''Théâtre des Folies-Marigny''' (26 March 1864).Lecomte 1905, [https://books.google.com/books?id=TKk-AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA28 p. 28]. Several early operettas of [[Charles Lecocq]] were performed here. The tenor [[Achille-Félix Montaubry]], who had formerly performed at the [[Opéra-Comique]] but had experienced a decline in the allure of his voice, purchased the Folies-Marigny in 1868, and produced an operetta of his own composition called ''Horace''.Fétis 1881, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Cu45AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA234#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 234]. In April 1870 the theatre was taken over by Leduc.''The Musical World'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=VJMPAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA289#v=onepage&q&f=false (23 April 1870), p. 289]. The last performance was in April 1881, and shortly thereafter it was demolished, to be replaced with a panorama designed by the architect [[Charles Garnier (architect)|Charles Garnier]]. In 1893 Garnier's panorama was converted by the architect [[Édouard Niermans (architect)|Édouard Niermans]] into a new theatre, which opened on 22 January 1896 under the name Folies-Marigny, but this was soon shortened to Marigny-Théâtre or [[Théâtre Marigny]].Lecomte 1905, pp. [https://books.google.com/books?id=TKk-AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA28 28], [https://books.google.com/books?id=TKk-AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA39 39]. ==References== ;Notes {{Reflist|2}} ;Sources * Duneton, Claude; Bigot, Emmanuelle (1998). {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2018}} {{short description|annual film festival held in Toronto, Ontario, Canada}} {{Coord|43|38|48|N|79|23|25|W|display = title}} {{Infobox Film Festival | name = Toronto International Film Festival | logo = Toronto International Film Festival logo.svg | logo_size = 130px | caption = [[King Street (Toronto)|King Street West]], [[2016 Toronto International Film Festival]] | image = TIFF comes in Toronto (29465981882).jpg | image_alt = King Street West pedestrianized for the opening of the 2016 Toronto International Film Festival <!-- | host = Toronto International Film Festival Group --> <!-- in 2009 the word "Group" was dropped from "Toronto International Film Festival Group" --> | number = Fewest, 85 (1978); most, 460 (1984)<ref>{{cite press release |url = http://www.torontointernationalfilmfestival.ca/press/pressreleases/2010/35th-anniversary-fact-sheet |publisher = Toronto International Film Festival |date = September 27, 2010 |title = 35th Anniversary Fact Sheet: TIFF Facts and Figures |accessdate = September 21, 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110706210439/http://www.torontointernationalfilmfestival.ca/press/pressreleases/2010/35th-anniversary-fact-sheet |archivedate = July 6, 2011 |df = }}</ref> | location = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada | language = International | founded = 1976 <!-- under a different name --> | website = {{url|http://tiff.net/}} }}
The '''Toronto International Film Festival''' ('''TIFF''', often stylized as '''tiff''') is one of the largest publicly attended [[film festival]]s in the world, attracting over 480,000 people annually. Since its founding in 1976, TIFF has grown to become a permanent destination for film culture operating out of the [[TIFF Bell Lightbox]], located in [[downtown Toronto]].
Year-round, the TIFF Bell Lightbox offers screenings, lectures, discussions, festivals, workshops, industry support, and the chance to meet filmmakers from Canada and around the world. TIFF Bell Lightbox is located on the north west corner of King Street and John Street in downtown Toronto.
In 2016, 397 films from 83 countries were screened at 28 screens in downtown Toronto venues, welcoming an estimated 480,000 attendees, over 5,000 of whom were industry professionals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://assets.contentful.com/22n7d68fswlw/3vWZvCErh6wWsq2kAkgySS/bcccc1803d208be54a3379c6c1cd38ac/Festival_Fact_Sheet_2016_.pdf|title=2016 TORONTO INTERNATIONAL FILM FESTIVAL FACT SHEET|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161024161741/http://assets.contentful.com/22n7d68fswlw/3vWZvCErh6wWsq2kAkgySS/bcccc1803d208be54a3379c6c1cd38ac/Festival_Fact_Sheet_2016_.pdf|archive-date=October 24, 2016|dead-url=no|access-date=|df=}}</ref> TIFF starts the Thursday night after Labour Day (the first Monday in September in Canada) and lasts for eleven days.
Founded in 1976, TIFF is now one of the largest and most prestigious events of its kind in the world.<ref name="BBCFound">{{cite news |url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-23681679 |title = Toronto 2013: Why the festival matters |accessdate = September 5, 2013 |work = [[BBC News]] |date = September 4, 2013 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130905180541/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-23681679 |archivedate = September 5, 2013 |df = }}</ref> In 1998, ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' magazine acknowledged that TIFF "is second only to [[Cannes Film Festival|Cannes]] in terms of high-profile pics, stars, and market activity". In 2007, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' noted that TIFF had "grown from its place as the most influential fall film festival to the most influential film festival, period".<ref>{{cite news |last = Keegan |first = Rebecca Winters |title = Big-Screen Romance |publisher = [[Time (magazine)|TIME]] |date = August 2007 |url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1657363,00.html/ |accessdate = May 28, 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101009100129/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1657363,00.html |archivedate = October 9, 2010 |df = }}</ref> This is partially the result of the festival's ability and reputation for generating "[[Academy Awards|Oscar]] buzz".<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-207_162-5322819.html |work = [[CBS News]] |date = September 19, 2009 |accessdate = August 25, 2011 |title = Toronto Film Festival: Oscar Buzz Begins |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121104122819/http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-207_162-5322819.html |archivedate = November 4, 2012 |df = }}</ref>
The festival's [[Toronto International Film Festival People's Choice Award|People's Choice Award]]—which is based on audience balloting—has emerged as an indicator of success in [[Film awards seasons|awards season]], especially at the [[Academy Awards]]. Past recipients of this award include Oscar-winning films, such as: ''[[Life Is Beautiful]]'', ''[[American Beauty (1999 film)|American Beauty]]'', ''[[Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon]]'', ''[[Slumdog Millionaire]]'', ''[[The King's Speech]]'', ''[[12 Years a Slave (film)|12 Years a Slave]]'', ''[[The Imitation Game]]'', ''[[Room (2015 film)|Room]]'', ''[[La La Land (film)|La La Land]]'', and ''[[Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri]]''.
The festival's current executive director is [[Piers Handling]], who is slated to be succeeded by [[Joana Vicente]] in November 2018.<ref>[https://nationalpost.com/entertainment/movies/everything-you-need-to-know-about-joana-vicente-tiffs-new-executive-director "Everything you need to know about Joana Vicente, TIFF's new executive director"]. ''[[National Post]]'', August 28, 2018.</ref> The festival's artistic director is [[Cameron Bailey]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tiff.net/the-review/cameron-bailey-appointed-co-head-of-tiff/|title=Cameron Bailey appointed Co-Head of TIFF|date=April 19, 2018|work=TIFF|access-date=September 17, 2018|language=en}}</ref>
==Background== The Toronto International Film Festival was first launched as the '''Toronto Festival of Festivals''', collecting the best films from other film festivals around the world and showing them to eager audiences in Toronto. Founded by [[Bill Marshall (producer)|Bill Marshall]], [[Dusty Cohl]], and [[Henk Van der Kolk]],<ref name=tstar>{{cite news |first=Peter |last=Goffin |title=TIFF co-founder Bill Marshall, 77, remembered as pioneer of Canadian film |url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/2017/01/01/tiff-co-founder-bill-marshall-77-remembered-as-pioneer-of-canadian-film.html |work=[[Toronto Star]] |publisher= |date=January 1, 2017 |accessdate=January 3, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170102173841/https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/2017/01/01/tiff-co-founder-bill-marshall-77-remembered-as-pioneer-of-canadian-film.html |archivedate=January 2, 2017 |df= }}</ref> the inaugural event took place from October 18 through 24, 1976. That first year, 35,000 filmgoers watched 127 films from 30 countries presented in ten programmes. [[Piers Handling]] has been the festival's director and CEO since 1994, while [[Noah Cowan]] became co-director of TIFF in 2004. In late 2007, Cowan became the artistic director of [[TIFF Bell Lightbox]], while longtime programmer [[Cameron Bailey]] succeeded as co-director. As of 2013, Bailey is now the artistic director of the Toronto International Film Festival, as well as TIFF Bell Lightbox's year round programming.<ref>[http://arts.nationalpost.com/2012/03/14/cameron-bailey-named-artistic-director-of-toronto-international-film-festival/ "Cameron Bailey named artistic director of Toronto International Film Festival"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20150121000908/http://arts.nationalpost.com/2012/03/14/cameron-bailey-named-artistic-director-of-toronto-international-film-festival/ |date=January 21, 2015 }}. ''[[National Post]]'', March 14, 2012.</ref>
TIFF was once centred on the [[Yorkville, Toronto|Yorkville]] neighbourhood, but the [[Toronto Entertainment District]] later gained a greater level of prominence.<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.thestar.com/article/851243 |work = [[Toronto Star]] |first = Raju |last = Mudhar |date = August 25, 2010 |accessdate = September 7, 2010 |title = From mega clubs to mega culture in Entertainment District |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100831074356/http://www.thestar.com/article/851243 |archivedate = August 31, 2010 |df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.toronto.com/article/696280?bn=1 |work = [[Toronto Star]] |first = Kate |last = Allen |date = August 24, 2011 |accessdate = August 25, 2011 |title = TIFF's great migration |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120323021413/http://www.toronto.com/article/696280?bn=1 |archivedate = March 23, 2012 |df = }}</ref><!-- As of 2013, TIFF maintains extensive connections with the Yorkville area.<ref>{{cite web |last = Moran |first = Andrew |title = Yorkville the hot spot in Toronto during film festival |publisher = [[DigitalJournal.com|Digital Journal]] |date = September 2009 |url = http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/279106 |accessdate = May 29, 2010 }}</ref> --> TIFF is known for the celebrity buzz it brings to the area with international media setting up near its restaurants and stores for photos and interviews with the stars. In 2010, TIFF opened its permanent headquarters, TIFF Bell Lightbox, a year-round home for the appreciation of film in the heart of downtown Toronto.
TIFF has grown, steadily adding initiatives throughout the years. TIFF Cinematheque (formerly Cinematheque Ontario) and the Film Reference Library (FRL) opened in 1990. The TIFF Kids International Film Festival (formerly Sprockets) launched in 1998. Film Circuit began exhibiting independent and Canadian films in under-serviced cities across Canada in 1994.
Key dates <ref>[https://www.tiff.net/tiff/pages/?tab=about TIFF About] TIFF Official Website</ref> of the TIFF come in late August (Official Film Schedule release) and early September (tickets go on sale first to the Patron Circle Members, TIFF Members, TIFF Insiders, and only then to the public).<ref>[https://rove.me/to/toronto/tiff-or-toronto-international-film-festival TIFF or Toronto International Film Festival] rove.me</ref>
==History== [[File:Day12filmfestboxoffice2.jpg|thumb|right|TIFF box office at the [[Manulife Centre]] in 2006]] The festival was founded in 1976 at the [[Windsor Arms Hotel]] by [[Bill Marshall (producer)|Bill Marshall]], Henk Van der Kolk and [[Dusty Cohl]].<ref>{{cite web |last = Stavrou |first = Philip |title = Film Festival events return to their roots |publisher = [[CTVglobemedia]] |date = September 2005 |url = http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20050912/WindsorArms_20050912/20050912/ |accessdate = September 19, 2014 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080210010908/http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20050912/WindsorArms_20050912/20050912/ |archivedate = February 10, 2008 |df = }}</ref> Beginning as a collection of the best-regarded films from film festivals around the world, it had an inaugural attendance of 35,000.<ref>{{cite press release |url = http://tiff.net/press/pressreleases/2010/35th-anniversary-fact-sheet |publisher = Toronto International Film Festival |date = September 27, 2010 |title = 35th Anniversary Fact Sheet: TIFF Facts and Figures |accessdate = September 21, 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100804042620/http://tiff.net/press/pressreleases/2010/35th-anniversary-fact-sheet |archivedate = August 4, 2010 |df = }}</ref> Ironically, however, Hollywood studios withdrew their submissions from TIFF due to concerns that Toronto audiences would be too parochial for their products.<ref>{{cite web |last = Sterritt |first = David |title = Film Festivals - Then and Now |publisher = [[FIPRESCI]] |date = April 2010 |url = http://www.fipresci.org/undercurrent/issue_0609/sterritt_festivals.htm |accessdate = June 8, 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130906171153/http://fipresci.org/undercurrent/issue_0609/sterritt_festivals.htm |archivedate = September 6, 2013 |df = }}</ref> In the years following, TIFF continued to concentrate on bringing the best films from around the world.{{Citation needed|date = September 2010}} Through consistent investment and promotion by its organisers and sponsors, the Toronto International Film Festival has also grown to become a vital component of [[Hollywood]]'s marketing machine.{{Citation needed|date = September 2010}}
In 1994, the decision was made to replace the name "Festival of Festivals" with "Toronto International Film Festival". From 1994 to 2009, the umbrella organization running TIFF was named "Toronto International Film Festival Group" (TIFFG). In 2009, the umbrella organization TIFFG was renamed to TIFF.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.torontointernationalfilmfestival.ca/abouttiff/organization/tiffhistory |title = TIFF History |accessdate = September 21, 2010 |publisher = Toronto International Film Festival |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100825030348/http://www.torontointernationalfilmfestival.ca/abouttiff/organization/tiffhistory |archivedate = August 25, 2010 |df = }}</ref>
In 2001, Perspective Canada, the programme that had focused on Canadian films since 1984, was replaced by two programmes: * Canada First!, a forum for Canadian filmmakers presenting their first feature-length work, featuring eight to 15 films, and * Short Cuts Canada, which includes 30-40 Canadian [[short film]]s.
In 2004, TIFF was featured as the site of murder mystery in the film ''[[Jiminy Glick in Lalawood]]'', a comedy film starring [[Martin Short]].
In 2007, it was announced that the organization generates an estimated annual impact of $67 million CAD.<ref>{{cite press release|work = [[Ontario Ministry of Tourism, Culture and Sport]]|date = September 7, 2007|title = McGuinty government helps promote Toronto International Film Festival|url = http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/47437/mcguinty-government-helps-promote-toronto-international-film-festival|accessdate = September 10, 2012|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130117004200/http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/47437/mcguinty-government-helps-promote-toronto-international-film-festival|archivedate = January 17, 2013|df = }}</ref> By 2011, that benefit had grown to $170 million CAD.<ref>{{cite press release |url = http://tiff.net/press/pressreleases/2011/festival-announces |publisher = Toronto International Film Festival |date = August 16, 2011 |title = Festival Announces Boundary-Pushing Visions Titles |accessdate = August 25, 2011 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110912052928/http://tiff.net/press/pressreleases/2011/festival-announces |archivedate = September 12, 2011 |df = }}</ref>
In 2008, [[Rose McGowan]] caused controversy at a TIFF press conference for her film ''[[Fifty Dead Men Walking]]'', when she noted that "I imagine, had I grown up in Belfast, I would 100% have been in the IRA."<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/film-tv/news/director-apologises-for-rose-mcgowans-ira-comments-13978481.html |work = [[Belfast Telegraph]] |date = 2008–2011|title = Director apologises for Rose McGowan's IRA comments|author = The Globe and Mail|agency = Phillip Crawley, Publisher}}</ref>

===Notable film premieres=== Films such as ''[[American Beauty (1999 film)|American Beauty]]'', ''[[Ray (film)|Ray]]'', ''[[Mr. Nobody (film)|Mr. Nobody]]'', ''[[127 Hours]]'', ''[[Black Swan (film)|Black Swan]]'', ''[[The Five Obstructions]]'', ''[[Singapore Sling (1990 film)|Singapore Sling]]'', and ''[[I Am Love (film)|I Am Love]]'' have premiered at TIFF. [[Jamie Foxx]]'s portrayal of [[Ray Charles]] ultimately won him the [[Academy Award for Best Actor]] while ''[[Slumdog Millionaire]]'' went on to win eight Oscars at the 2009 Academy Awards. ''[[Precious (film)|Precious]]'', which won the 2009 TIFF People's Choice Award, went on to win two Oscars at the 82nd Academy Awards. ''[[The King's Speech]]'', the winner of the 2010 TIFF People's Choice Award, won four Oscars at the 83rd Academy Awards, while ''[[Silver Linings Playbook]]'', the winner of the 2012 TIFF People's Choice Award, went on to win the [[Academy Award for Best Actress]] for [[Jennifer Lawrence]].
Many Hollywood studios premiere their films in Toronto due to TIFF's easy-going non-competitive nature, relatively inexpensive costs (when compared to European festivals), eager film-fluent audiences and convenient timing.<ref>{{cite news |last = Ebert |first = Roger |title = Starting off the season |publisher = [[Chicago Sun-Times]] |date = September 2008 |url = http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080904/FILMFESTIVALS03/809049995/-1/FILMFESTIVALS |accessdate = June 8, 2010 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120622053750/http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20080904%2FFILMFESTIVALS03%2F809049995%2F-1%2FFILMFESTIVALS |archivedate = June 22, 2012 |df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |work = [[The Canadian Press]] |title = TIFF unspools with celebrities eager to connect with fans |publisher = [[CTV Television Network|CTV]] |date = September 2009 |url = http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20090908/TIFF_fans_090908?s_name=tiff2009&no_ads= |accessdate = June 8, 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last = Rich |first = Joshua |title = Fest intentions |publisher = [[Entertainment Weekly]] |date = January 2005 |url = http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,695291,00.html |accessdate = June 8, 2010 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110606235945/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,695291,00.html |archivedate = June 6, 2011 |df = }}</ref>
===TIFF Bell Lightbox=== [[File:Lightbox 2010-09-11 II.JPG|thumb|[[TIFF Bell Lightbox]]]] In 2007, the Festival Group began construction on [[TIFF Bell Lightbox]], a new facility at the corner of King and John Streets in downtown Toronto, on land donated by [[Ivan Reitman]] and family. The $181 million facility is named for founding sponsor [[Bell Canada]], with additional support from the [[Government of Ontario]] and [[Government of Canada]].
In 2010, the organization opened its new headquarters at TIFF Bell Lightbox. The facility, designed by local firm [[KPMB Architects]], provides extensive year-round galleries, cinemas, archives and activities for cinephiles.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/arts/tiff/interviews-and-features/article1702853.ece | location = Toronto | work = [[The Globe and Mail]] | first = Guy | last = Dixon | title = Lightbox aims to draw filmmakers to its facilities - The Globe and Mail | date = September 9, 2010 }}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The five-storey facility contains five cinemas, two gallery spaces, film archives and an extensive reference library, study spaces, film lab facility, and a research centre. There is also a gift shop, two restaurants, a lounge, a cafe, and a three-storey atrium.<ref>{{cite news|title = Let there be lightbox|url = http://www.nowtoronto.com/movies/story.cfm?content=176653|accessdate = August 17, 2012|work = NOW|date = September 9–16, 2010|author = Norman Wilner|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130117004724/http://www.nowtoronto.com/movies/story.cfm?content=176653|archivedate = January 17, 2013|df = }}</ref> Cooperatively with Daniels Corporation, there is a 46-storey condominium atop, called the Festival Tower.
The first film screening was [[Bruce McDonald (director)|Bruce McDonald]]'s ''[[Trigger (film)|Trigger]]''. The first exhibition was a retrospective on [[Tim Burton]], organized by the [[Museum of Modern Art]] (New York). Subsequent exhibitions include Fellini: Spectacular Obsessions, Grace Kelly: From Movie Star to Princess, Designing 007: 50 Years of Bond Style, and [[Stanley Kubrick]]: The Exhibition, all of which were organized by TIFF, as well as one called ''Essential Cinema'', featuring posters, images and props from TIFF's ''The Essential 100'' list of films.<ref>{{cite news|title = No place like home: Toronto film fest opens new HQ|url = http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2010/sep/09/no-place-like-home-toronto-film-fest-opens-new-hq/|accessdate = September 16, 2012|work = U-T San Diego News|date = September 9, 2010|first = David|last = Germain|agency = The San Diego Union-Tribune, LLC|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130117004159/http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2010/sep/09/no-place-like-home-toronto-film-fest-opens-new-hq/|archivedate = January 17, 2013|df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title = A look at the Stanley Kubrick Exhibition TIFF 2014|url = http://blogs.vancouversun.com/2014/11/27/stanley-kubrick-tiff-2014/|accessdate = August 3, 2015|work = [[The Vancouver Sun]]|date = November 27, 2014|agency = Canoe Sun Media}}</ref>
The [[Film Reference Library]] (FRL) is a large Canadian film research collection. The library is a free resource for film lovers, filmmakers, students, scholars, and journalists, and is located on the fourth floor of the TIFF Bell Lightbox. An affiliate member of the [[International Federation of Film Archives|International Federation of Film Archives (FIAF)]], the FRL promotes Canadian and global film scholarship by collecting, preserving, and providing access to a comprehensive collection of film prints, and film-related reference resources (including books, periodicals, scripts, research files, movies, press kits, and about 80 special collections.
In 2016, the festival received a donation of 1,400 film prints, and launched a campaign to raise money for the preservation and storage of the films.<ref>[https://www.pressreader.com/canada/toronto-star/20161116/282033326780443 "TIFF gains cach of 1,400 film prints"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161117065918/https://www.pressreader.com/canada/toronto-star/20161116/282033326780443 |date=November 17, 2016 }}. ''Toronto Star'', November 16, 2016. Page E2.</ref>
===Canada's Top Ten=== Each year, TIFF also releases a list of the films selected by festival programmers as the ten best Canadian feature and short films of the year, regardless of whether or not they were screened at TIFF.<ref name=topten>[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/film/tiff-reveals-canadas-top-ten-film-festival-line-up/article27649543/ "TIFF reveals Canada’s Top Ten Film Festival line-up"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222182936/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/film/tiff-reveals-canadas-top-ten-film-festival-line-up/article27649543/ |date=December 22, 2015 }}. ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', December 8, 2015.</ref> The films selected are announced in December each year, and are screened at a smaller follow-up festival at the Lightbox the following January;<ref name = topten /> a People's Choice Award is then presented for that minifestival as well.
Since 1984, every decade TIFF has also produced a [[Top 10 Canadian Films of All Time]] list. This list is produced from a wider poll of film industry professionals and academics throughout Canada, separately from the annual top-ten list.
==Awards== The festival's major prize, the [[Toronto International Film Festival People's Choice Award|People's Choice Award]], is given to a feature-length film. It is not a juried prize, but is given to the film with the highest ratings as voted by the TIFF-going populace.<ref>{{cite news |last = Walmsley |first = Katie |title = Oprah flick 'Precious' wins top award at Toronto |publisher = [[CNN]] |date = September 2009 |url = http://edition.cnn.com/2009/SHOWBIZ/Movies/09/21/toronto.film.festival.wrap/ |accessdate = June 8, 2010 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120526231657/http://edition.cnn.com/2009/SHOWBIZ/Movies/09/21/toronto.film.festival.wrap/ |archivedate = May 26, 2012 |df = }}</ref> It is presently referred to as the "[[Grolsch]] People's Choice Award";<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tiff.net/the-review/you-pick-the-winner-how-to-vote-for-the-grolsch-peoples-choice-award/ |title=You Pick the Winner: How to Vote for the Grolsch People's Choice Award |year=2016 |publisher=TIFF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170825042925/https://www.tiff.net/the-review/you-pick-the-winner-how-to-vote-for-the-grolsch-peoples-choice-award/ |archivedate=August 25, 2017 |df= |access-date=August 25, 2017 }}</ref> past sponsors of the award have included [[Cadillac]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nationalpost.com/entertainment/lebanese-film-wins-tiff-peoples-choice-award |publisher=National Post |author=Chris Knight |title=Lebanese film wins TIFF People's Choice Award |date=September 18, 2011}}</ref> The winners of this award have often later earned [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] nominations.<ref>[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/awards-and-festivals/tiff/the-imitation-game-wins-peoples-choice-award-at-tiff/article20593656/ "‘The Imitation Game’ wins top prize at TIFF"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161117063326/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/awards-and-festivals/tiff/the-imitation-game-wins-peoples-choice-award-at-tiff/article20593656/ |date=November 17, 2016 }}. ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', September 14, 2014.</ref> People's Choice Awards are also presented for [[Toronto International Film Festival People's Choice Award: Documentaries|Documentary]] and [[Toronto International Film Festival People's Choice Award: Midnight Madness|Midnight Madness]] films. Each of the People's Choice Awards names first and second runners-up in addition to the winners.
However, TIFF does present juried awards in some other categories. The festival presents three major awards for Canadian films: [[Toronto International Film Festival Award for Best Canadian Film|Best Canadian Film]], [[Toronto International Film Festival Award for Best Canadian First Feature Film|Best Canadian First Feature Film]], and [[Toronto International Film Festival Award for Best Canadian Short Film|Best Canadian Short Film]], as well as international awards for Best Short Film, two [[FIPRESCI]]-sponsored Special Presentation and Discovery awards for international films, and a [[NETPAC]]-sponsored award for the best film from [[Asia]] having its world premiere at the festival.<ref>{{cite web |last = Knegt |first = Peter |title = 'Precious' tops Toronto winners |publisher = [[IndieWire]] |date = September 2009 |url = http://www.indiewire.com/article/toronto_film_festival_award_winners/ |accessdate = June 8, 2010 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100829190219/http://www.indiewire.com/article/toronto_film_festival_award_winners |archivedate = August 29, 2010 |df = }}</ref>
In 2015, the festival introduced Platform, a juried programme that champions director’s cinema from around the world; one film from the stream is selected as the winner of the [[Platform Prize]].
For all of the juried awards, [[honorable mention]]s may also be given, although the juries are expected to select one overall winner.
==Sections== The hundreds of films screened at the annual festival are divided into sections (referred to by TIFF as "Programmes") based on genre (e.g. [[documentary]], [[children's film]]s), format (e.g. [[short films]], [[television episode]]s), the status of filmmaker (e.g. "masters", first-time directors), and so forth. Up until the early 2010s there were sections reserved for Canadian films, but beginning in 2015 all Canadian films are integrated in sections with films from outside Canada.
Currently the festival's 14 sections are as follows:<ref name=TIFF2017sections/> * Contemporary World Cinema: [[narrative film|narrative]] feature films generally by directors who are established but not famous * Discovery: films that are typically the director's first or second [[feature film]] * Gala Presentations: high-profile feature films, often featuring international movie stars, presented with a [[red carpet]] * In Conversation With...: interviews of a director or other figure from the film industry, generally accompanied by brief excerpts from films (up until the [[2014 Toronto International Film Festival|2014 festival]], this section was called "Mavericks") * Masters: feature films by "the world's most influential [[art-house]] filmmakers" * Midnight Madness: [[genre film]]s (traditionally at TIFF each film in this section has one screening scheduled for 11:59pm and another the following afternoon); the section was launched at TIFF in 1988 and was programmed by Colin Geddes from 1998 to 2016,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.indiewire.com/2017/02/tiff-programmer-colin-geddes-steps-down-toronto-international-film-festival-1201778911/ |work=IndieWire |title=TIFF Programmer Colin Geddes Departing After 20 Years |author=Graham Winfrey |date=February 7, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170225210306/http://www.indiewire.com/2017/02/tiff-programmer-colin-geddes-steps-down-toronto-international-film-festival-1201778911/ |archivedate=February 25, 2017 |df= }}</ref> now programmed by Peter Kuplowsky * Platform: a competitive section launched in 2015, named for [[Jia Zhangke]]'s film ''[[Platform (2000 film)|Platform]]'', of films from around the world that do not have distribution in North America.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.indiewire.com/2015/07/why-the-toronto-film-festival-is-adding-platform-competition-sidebar-186045/ |title=Why the Toronto Film Festival is Adding ‘Platform’ Competition Sidebar |date=July 15, 2015 |author=Anne Thompson |website=IndieWire |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224132235/http://www.indiewire.com/2015/07/why-the-toronto-film-festival-is-adding-platform-competition-sidebar-186045/ |archivedate=February 24, 2017 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |work=The Hollywood Reporter |author=Etan Vlessing |title=Toronto: Natalie Portman's 'Jackie' Biopic, 'Moonlight' From Brad Pitt's Plan B Join Lineup |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/tiff-2016-platform-lineup-natalie-918884 |date=August 11, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160811230426/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/tiff-2016-platform-lineup-natalie-918884 |archivedate=August 11, 2016 |df= }}</ref> Every year the Platform section has a high-profile international jury which confers a prize of C$25,000; both documentaries and narrative films are eligible for inclusion in the section; prior winners of the Platform Prize are the Canadian documentary ''[[Hurt (2015 film)|HURT]]'' (2015), the biographical drama ''[[Jackie (2016 film)|Jackie]]'' (2016) and ''[[Sweet Country (2017 film)|Sweet Country]]'' (2017). * Primetime: television episodes making either their world premiere or North American premiere projected cinematically; this section was launched in 2015 * Short Cuts: a section of [[short films]] (usually six to ten short films included at each screening) both Canadian and international; up until [[2013 Toronto International Film Festival|the 2013 festival]] only Canadian short films were screened and the section was called Short Cuts Canada, in [[2014 Toronto International Film Festival|2014]] a new section called Short Cuts International was added, and then in 2015 they were merged into a section called Short Cuts * Special Presentations: high-profile feature films, usually Canadian premieres if not [[premiere|world premieres]] * TIFF Cinematheque: unlike the other sections which present new films, the TIFF Cinematheque section has films from all eras of cinema, often classic films that have been newly [[film preservation|restored]] * TIFF Docs (formerly called Reel to Reel): [[documentary]] films * TIFF Kids and TIFF Next Wave (formerly called Sprockets): films for children and teenagers * Wavelengths: [[experimental film]]s and [[art film]]s, both feature-length and shorts (this section was named for [[Michael Snow]]'s film ''[[Wavelength (1967 film)|Wavelength]]'')
In previous years, sections at TIFF have included Canada First!, City to City ([[2009 Toronto International Film Festival#Controversy over Tel Aviv spotlight|2009]] to 2016), Future Projections, Vanguard (up to 2016), and Visions (up to 2011).
==Media coverage==
In 2016, TIFF hosted 1,800 members of the press and print media outlets such as the ''[[Toronto Star]]'', ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[The Times of India]]'', ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'', ''[[Miami Herald]]'', and the ''[[Toronto Sun]]'' have published a significant amount of festival coverage.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dargis|first1=Manohla|title=Toronto Film Festival: Separating Contenders From Pretenders|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/19/movies/toronto-film-festivalseparating-contenders-from-pretenders.html?_r=0|accessdate=May 15, 2017|publisher=The New York Times|date=September 18, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171213143733/https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/19/movies/toronto-film-festivalseparating-contenders-from-pretenders.html?_r=0|archivedate=December 13, 2017|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Kirkland|first1=Bruce|title=TIFF 2015: The most fascinating films that closed the festival|url=http://www.torontosun.com/2015/09/18/tiff-2015-the-most-fascinating-films-that-closed-the-festival|accessdate=May 15, 2017|publisher=Toronto Sun|date=September 18, 2015}}</ref> Also, the major industry trade magazines ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' and ''[[Screen International]]'' all produce daily editions during TIFF. TIFF reports also appear in weekly news magazines; American, Canadian and international entertainment shows; news services; and a wide range of film and celebrity blogs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cinema-scope.com/tiff-reviews-home-page/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=December 13, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171025063250/http://cinema-scope.com/tiff-reviews-home-page/ |archivedate=October 25, 2017 |df= }}</ref>
